message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenocarcinoma at the head of the pancreas can obstruct the bile duct leading to a palpable gallbladder. Lymphadenopathy of the umbilicus suggests metastasis to the periumbilical lymph nodes, acanthosis nigricans suggests insulin resistance which can be associated with diabetes mellitus but not specific to adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, and splenomegaly is not a common finding in adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenocarcinoma of the head of the pancreas can cause obstruction of the bile duct, leading to palpable gallbladder. Lymphadenopathy of the umbilicus is associated with metastatic cancer, but not specific to pancreatic cancer. Acanthosis nigricans is associated with insulin resistance, which is common in diabetes mellitus. Splenomegaly is not a typical finding in pancreatic cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only a palpable gallbladder would support the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma at the head of the pancreas. Lymphadenopathy of the umbilicus suggests metastasis in the periumbilical lymph nodes (Sister Mary Joseph nodule), acanthosis nigricans suggests insulin resistance, and splenomegaly suggests diseases such as lymphoma or myeloproliferative disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenocarcinoma at the head of the pancreas can cause obstruction of the common bile duct, leading to palpable gallbladder. Lymphadenopathy of the umbilicus is associated with metastatic adenocarcinoma, but it is known as Sister Mary Joseph nodule. Acanthosis nigricans and splenomegaly are not specific to pancreatic cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenocarcinoma of the head of the pancreas can cause obstruction of the common bile duct, leading to jaundice and palpable gallbladder. Lymphadenopathy of the umbilicus is associated with metastatic gastric cancer. Acanthosis nigricans is related to insulin resistance and is seen in diabetes but is not specific to pancreatic cancer. Splenomegaly is not typically associated with pancreatic cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenocarcinoma of the head of the pancreas can cause an obstruction of the common bile duct leading to a palpable gallbladder. Lymphadenopathy of the umbilicus is called Sister Mary Joseph nodule and can suggest metastasis in cases of intra-abdominal malignancy, but it is not a specific finding for pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Acanthosis nigricans is associated with insulin resistance and diabetes mellitus. Splenomegaly can be seen in certain cancers, but it is not specific to pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The head of the pancreas lies near the gallbladder, so a palpable gallbladder suggests that the tumor may have spread to the gallbladder. Lymphadenopathy of the umbilicus (Sister Mary Joseph nodule) is a sign of advanced disease, but is not specific to adenocarcinoma at the head of the pancreas. Acanthosis nigricans is associated with hyperinsulinemia or insulin resistance, but is not specific to pancreatic cancer. Splenomegaly is associated with hematologic disorders, but not specific to pancreatic cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenocarcinoma at the head of the pancreas can obstruct the common bile duct, leading to jaundice and a palpable gallbladder. Option (A) is a sign of metastasis to the umbilical lymph nodes (Sister Mary Joseph nodule). Option (B) is a sign of insulin resistance but not specific to pancreatic cancer. Option (D) may occur with advanced pancreatic cancer but is not specific to adenocarcinoma at the head of the pancreas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the suspected adenocarcinoma is at the head of the pancreas, which is near the gallbladder. Palpable gallbladder is a classic physical examination finding that supports the diagnosis. Lymphadenopathy of the umbilicus indicates Sister Mary Joseph's nodule, which is a sign of metastatic cancer. Acanthosis nigricans is a skin manifestation of insulin resistance and is not specific to pancreatic cancer. Splenomegaly is not a common finding in pancreatic cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenocarcinoma of the pancreas at the head may cause obstruction of the bile duct, leading to jaundice and a palpable gallbladder. Acanthosis nigricans is associated with insulin resistance and diabetes mellitus, but it is not a physical finding suggestive of pancreatic cancer. Lymphadenopathy of the umbilicus (Sister Mary Joseph nodule) and splenomegaly may indicate metastasis, but they are not specific to pancreatic cancer.
